channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Failed PhD: how scientists have bounced back from doctoral setbacks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02603-8

In a scientific culture that eschews admitting failure, some researchers are staring it in the face — and finding success.
item.dc:title: Failed PhD: how scientists have bounced back from doctoral setbacks
item.dc:creator: Carrie Arnold

item.title: From better bridges to more efficient cars: how pocket calculators changed the world
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02601-w

Now lying forgotten in many a drawer, the modern computer’s handheld predecessors heralded an era of effortless calculation — an innovation 42,000 years in the making.
item.dc:title: From better bridges to more efficient cars: how pocket calculators changed the world
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey M. Perkel

item.title: Want to speed up scientific progress? First understand how science policy works
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02602-9

Researchers and policymakers often exist in different worlds and speak different languages. Here are three ways to bridge the divide.
item.dc:title: Want to speed up scientific progress? First understand how science policy works
item.dc:creator: Matt Clancy
Dan Correa
Jordan Dworkin
Paul Niehaus
Caleb Watney
Heidi Williams

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06543-1

Author Correction: Rewiring cancer drivers to activate apoptosis
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Rewiring cancer drivers to activate apoptosis

item.title: The complexity of viruses, and understanding pain: Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02634-1

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: The complexity of viruses, and understanding pain: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: WHO’s first traditional medicine summit splits opinions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02636-z

The World Health Organization says the world-first summit will take an evidence-based approach — some are sceptical that much progress will be made.
item.dc:title: WHO’s first traditional medicine summit splits opinions
item.dc:creator: Gayathri Vaidyanathan

item.title: How a lupus diagnosis taught me that resilience in science is a double-edged sword
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02639-w

The ability to persevere through hardship is celebrated in research, but a ‘one size fits all’ approach can perpetuate inequalities, says Caitlin Aamodt.
item.dc:title: How a lupus diagnosis taught me that resilience in science is a double-edged sword
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Aamodt

item.title: What is an embryo? Scientists say definition needs to change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02641-2

Lab-grown structures with the potential to develop into fetuses should be defined — and regulated — as embryos, some researchers say.
item.dc:title: What is an embryo? Scientists say definition needs to change
item.dc:creator: Philip Ball

item.title: Earth’s hottest month: these charts show what happened in July and what comes next
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02552-2

The planet has warmed 1.2 ºC on average, but that’s enough to produce big extremes.
item.dc:title: Earth’s hottest month: these charts show what happened in July and what comes next
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

Observation of Fractionally Quantized Anomalous Hall Effect

item.content:encoded:

Publisher Correction: Pluripotent stem cell-derived model of the post-implantation human embryo

item.title: In search of a vaccine for leishmaniasis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02580-y

Researchers hope that immunization will provide much needed protection against the neglected parasitic disease in conflict zones.
item.dc:title: In search of a vaccine for leishmaniasis
item.dc:creator: Anthony King

item.title: The Indigenous rocketeer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02635-0

Nicole McGaa combined Indigenous knowledge with engineering to build a rocket for the First Nations Launch competition.
item.dc:title: The Indigenous rocketeer
item.dc:creator: Abdullahi Tsanni

item.title: I’m a climate scientist. Here’s how I’m handling climate grief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02619-0

Researchers must find personal ways to cope with impending losses — one way is by taking small solutions-oriented actions, says Kimberley R. Miner.
item.dc:title: I’m a climate scientist. Here’s how I’m handling climate grief
item.dc:creator: Kimberley R. Miner

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06508-4

Endothelial sensing of AHR ligands regulates intestinal homeostasis
item.dc:title: Endothelial sensing of AHR ligands regulates intestinal homeostasis

item.title: Brain mitochondria predict a mouse’s stress level
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02575-9

The number and DNA content of power-producing organelles in the brain account for part of the behavioural variation amongst mice.
item.dc:title: Brain mitochondria predict a mouse’s stress level

item.title: Melting glaciers will reveal vast new ecosystems in need of protection
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02564-y

The emerging habitats represent huge ecological shifts and present new challenges for conservation.
item.dc:title: Melting glaciers will reveal vast new ecosystems in need of protection
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: Ötzi the Iceman has a new look: balding and dark-skinned
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02562-0

Improved DNA analysis updates thinking on alpine mummy’s skin colour, ancestry and more.
item.dc:title: Ötzi the Iceman has a new look: balding and dark-skinned
item.dc:creator: Freda Kreier

item.title: Fruit flies’ ability to sense magnetic fields thrown into doubt
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02590-w

Study fails to replicate two key papers on fruit flies’ magnetic sense, and what the closing of the Arecibo observatory means for science.
item.dc:title: Fruit flies’ ability to sense magnetic fields thrown into doubt
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Shamini Bundell

item.title: Magneto-optics in a van der Waals magnet tuned by self-hybridized polaritons
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06275-2

In the layered magnetic semiconductor CrSBr, emergent light–matter hybrids (polaritons) increase the spectral bandwidth of correlations between the magnetic, electronic and optical properties, enabling largely tunable optical responses to applied magnetic fields and magnons.
item.dc:title: Magneto-optics in a van der Waals magnet tuned by self-hybridized polaritons

item.title: The future transistors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06145-x

The challenges and opportunities for the design of field-effect transistors are discussed and a vision of future transistors and potential innovation opportunities is provided.
item.dc:title: The future transistors
item.dc:creator: Wei Cao
Huiming Bu
Maud Vinet
Min Cao
Shinichi Takagi

item.title: Long-molecule scars of backup DNA repair in BRCA1- and BRCA2-deficient cancers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06461-2

Linked-read whole-genome sequencing reveals patterns of structural DNA variants that are specific to homologous recombination deficiency and can be used to distinguish between BRCA1- and BRCA2-deficient phenotypes.
item.dc:title: Long-molecule scars of backup DNA repair in BRCA1- and BRCA2-deficient cancers

item.title: Xiphoid nucleus of the midline thalamus controls cold-induced food seeking
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06430-9

Through leverage of whole-brain screening, in vivo calcium imaging and chemo- and optogenetic manipulations, it is demonstrated that the xiphoid nucleus serves as a key brain region in the promotion of cold-induced food-seeking behaviours.
item.dc:title: Xiphoid nucleus of the midline thalamus controls cold-induced food seeking
item.dc:creator: Neeraj K. Lal

item.title: Endothelial AHR activity prevents lung barrier disruption in viral infection
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06287-y

The environmental sensor aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AHR) and diet-derived AHR ligands play an important part in protecting against tissue damage following viral pathogen infection in the lung.
item.dc:title: Endothelial AHR activity prevents lung barrier disruption in viral infection
item.dc:creator: Jack Major

item.title: Interferon-ε is a tumour suppressor and restricts ovarian cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06421-w

Interferon-ε is a tumour suppressor expressed in the epithelial cell of origin of ovarian cancer, which it restricts by direct action on tumour cells and especially by activation of anti-tumour immunity.
item.dc:title: Interferon-ε is a tumour suppressor and restricts ovarian cancer
item.dc:creator: Zoe R. C. Marks

item.title: Nuclear genetic control of mtDNA copy number and heteroplasmy in humans
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06426-5

We quantify mitochondrial DNA copy number and heteroplasmy levels and study their association with nuclear genetic loci in population-scale biobanks.
item.dc:title: Nuclear genetic control of mtDNA copy number and heteroplasmy in humans
item.dc:creator: Rahul Gupta

item.title: Quantum textures of the many-body wavefunctions in magic-angle graphene
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06226-x

High-resolution scanning tunnelling microscopy is used to observe the quantum textures of the many-body wavefunctions of the correlated insulating, pseudogap and superconducting phases in magic-angle graphene.
item.dc:title: Quantum textures of the many-body wavefunctions in magic-angle graphene
item.dc:creator: Kevin P. Nuckolls

item.title: A viral ADP-ribosyltransferase attaches RNA chains to host proteins
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06429-2

Bacteriophage T4 uses an enzyme known as ADP-ribosyltransferase ModB to modify the translational apparatus of bacteria it infects, not only by ADP-ribosylating proteins, but also by attaching entire RNA chains in a process known as RNAylation.
item.dc:title: A viral ADP-ribosyltransferase attaches RNA chains to host proteins
item.dc:creator: Maik Wolfram-Schauerte
Nadiia Pozhydaieva

item.title: Platelet factors attenuate inflammation and rescue cognition in ageing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06436-3

Platelet factors transfer the benefits of young blood to the ageing brain in mice through CXCR3, which mediates the cellular, molecular and cognitive benefits of systemic PF4 on the aged brain.
item.dc:title: Platelet factors attenuate inflammation and rescue cognition in ageing
item.dc:creator: Adam B. Schroer

item.title: Transient naive reprogramming corrects hiPS cells functionally and epigenetically
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06424-7

A new reprogramming strategy used to produce human induced pluripotent stem cells from somatic cells results in epigenetic and functional profiles that are highly similar to those of human embryonic stem cells.
item.dc:title: Transient naive reprogramming corrects hiPS cells functionally and epigenetically
item.dc:creator: Sam Buckberry

item.title: Global methane emissions from rivers and streams
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06344-6

A spatially explicit global estimate reveals that land–water connections are important for regulating methane supply to running waters, and that these connections are vulnerable to both climate change and direct human modifications of the land.
item.dc:title: Global methane emissions from rivers and streams
item.dc:creator: Gerard Rocher-Ros
Emily H. Stanley
Luke C. Loken
Nora J. Casson
Peter A. Raymond
Shaoda Liu
Giuseppe Amatulli
Ryan A. Sponseller

item.title: Microstructure and crystal order during freezing of supercooled water drops
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06283-2

Optical microscopy and X-ray diffraction are used to study the freezing of water droplets in vacuum, leading to the development of a seven-stage model of freezing and the mapping of ice structures and crystal order.
item.dc:title: Microstructure and crystal order during freezing of supercooled water drops
item.dc:creator: Armin Kalita
Maximillian Mrozek-McCourt

item.title: High-entropy halide perovskite single crystals stabilized by mild chemistry
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06396-8

Room-temperature-solution (20 °C) and low-temperature-solution (80 °C) synthesis procedures are developed for a new class of metal halide perovskite high-entropy semiconductor single crystals.
item.dc:title: High-entropy halide perovskite single crystals stabilized by mild chemistry
item.dc:creator: Maria C. Folgueras
Yuxin Jiang
Jianbo Jin
Peidong Yang

item.title: Mapping the T cell repertoire to a complex gut bacterial community
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06431-8

Germ-free mice were colonized with complex defined communities to show T cell recognition of commensals is focused on widely conserved, highly expressed cell-surface antigens, opening the door to new therapeutic strategies.
item.dc:title: Mapping the T cell repertoire to a complex gut bacterial community
item.dc:creator: Kazuki Nagashima
Aishan Zhao

item.title: Persistent equatorial Pacific iron limitation under ENSO forcing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06439-0

An assessment of variations in phytoplankton nutrient limitation in the tropical Pacific over the past two decades finds that phytoplankton iron limitation is more stable in response to ENSO dynamics than models predict.
item.dc:title: Persistent equatorial Pacific iron limitation under ENSO forcing
item.dc:creator: Thomas J. Browning

item.title: Direct observation of the conformational states of PIEZO1
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06427-4

The plasma membrane can expand the blades of the PIEZO1 ion channel, impacting channel activation.
item.dc:title: Direct observation of the conformational states of PIEZO1

item.title: Future emergence of new ecosystems caused by glacial retreat
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06302-2

By 2100, the decline of all glaciers outside the Antarctic and Greenland ice sheets will produce new terrestrial, marine and freshwater ecosystems, posing both challenges and opportunities for conservation.
item.dc:title: Future emergence of new ecosystems caused by glacial retreat
item.dc:creator: J. B. Bosson
M. Huss
S. Cauvy-Fraunié
J. C. Clément
G. Costes
M. Fischer
J. Poulenard
F. Arthaud

item.title: Reversible spin-optical interface in luminescent organic radicals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06222-1

We report organic molecules showing both efficient luminescence and near-unity generation yield of excited states with high spin multiplicity, simultaneously supporting a high efficiency of initialization, spin manipulations and light-based readout at room temperature.
item.dc:title: Reversible spin-optical interface in luminescent organic radicals
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Gorgon

item.title: New reptile shows dinosaurs and pterosaurs evolved among diverse precursors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06359-z

A well-preserved partial skeleton (Upper Triassic, Brazil) of the new lagerpetid Venetoraptor gassenae gen. et sp. nov. offers a more comprehensive look into the skull and ecology of dinosaur and pterosaur precursors.
item.dc:title: New reptile shows dinosaurs and pterosaurs evolved among diverse precursors
item.dc:creator: Rodrigo T. Müller

Sterling J. Nesbitt

item.title: Proximity superconductivity in atom-by-atom crafted quantum dots
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06312-0

Proximity-induced superconductivity on a single spin-degenerate quantum level of a surface state confined in a quantum corral on a superconducting substrate built atom by atom by a scanning tunnelling microscope is investigated.
item.dc:title: Proximity superconductivity in atom-by-atom crafted quantum dots
item.dc:creator: Lucas Schneider
Khai That Ton
Ioannis Ioannidis
Jannis Neuhaus-Steinmetz
Thore Posske
Roland Wiesendanger
Jens Wiebe

item.title: Daily briefing: Listen to a Pink Floyd song reconstructed from people’s brainwaves
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02629-y

Scientists can eavesdrop on the music people are listening to by analysing their brain waves. Plus, how to make business and finance genuinely sustainable, and what it would take to answer the century’s biggest computing questions.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Listen to a Pink Floyd song reconstructed from people’s brainwaves
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Neural basis of why mammals eat more in the cold
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02384-0

Feeding and the maintenance of internal body temperature are tightly linked in warm-blooded animals, and mammals eat more in the cold to maintain their body heat. Experiments reveal that a small nucleus in the brain’s thalamus controls feeding behaviour specifically in cold conditions by directly activating a reward centre in the brain.
item.dc:title: Neural basis of why mammals eat more in the cold

item.title: Reducing inequality benefits everyone — so why isn’t it happening?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02551-3

Those urging world leaders to take action on inequality should study why earlier efforts did not translate to changes in policy.
item.dc:title: Reducing inequality benefits everyone — so why isn’t it happening?

item.title: Clues to rain formation found in droplet images
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02353-7

X-ray and optical imaging have revealed the intricate process through which droplets freeze during the formation of rain. The results could help to explain how clouds are able to produce enough ice particles to make rain.
item.dc:title: Clues to rain formation found in droplet images
item.dc:creator: Thomas Leisner

item.title: How I used weaponized laziness to build better collaborations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02591-9

Work smarter, not harder, by building tools to streamline your workflow, says Beth Cimini.
item.dc:title: How I used weaponized laziness to build better collaborations
item.dc:creator: Beth Cimini

item.title: Older mouse brains rejuvenated by protein found in young blood
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02563-z

A platelet factor joins the list of blood components that might have anti-ageing effects.
item.dc:title: Older mouse brains rejuvenated by protein found in young blood
item.dc:creator: Saima May Sidik

item.title: Thousands of scientists are cutting back on Twitter, seeding angst and uncertainty
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02554-0

A Nature survey reveals scientists’ reasons for leaving the social-media platform now known as X, and what they are doing to build and maintain a sense of community.
item.dc:title: Thousands of scientists are cutting back on Twitter, seeding angst and uncertainty
item.dc:creator: Myriam Vidal Valero

item.title: Cyber junk
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02561-1

Memories are made of this?
item.dc:title: Cyber junk
item.dc:creator: Sylvia Spruck Wrigley

item.title: The great melt will shape unprotected ecosystems
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02490-z

Glaciers should be prioritized in conservation agendas — and soon. Analysis suggests that glaciers could lose around half their area by the century’s end, with uncertain consequences for postglacial ecosystems.
item.dc:title: The great melt will shape unprotected ecosystems
item.dc:creator: Nicolas Lecomte

item.title: The quest to map the mouse brain
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02559-9

By combining single-cell sequencing with methods to map the spatial location of gene expression, scientists are unravelling the extraordinary cellular diversity of the brain.
item.dc:title: The quest to map the mouse brain
item.dc:creator: Diana Kwon

item.title: Mitochondrial DNA comes with nuclear strings attached
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01783-7

A genetic analysis provides the most-detailed glimpse yet of how genetic variants in nuclear DNA regulate the copy number and variability of DNA housed in organelles called mitochondria.
item.dc:title: Mitochondrial DNA comes with nuclear strings attached
item.dc:creator: Sonia Boscenco
Ed Reznik

item.title: A global picture of methane emissions from rivers and streams
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02286-1

Methane is a potent greenhouse gas. A global data analysis measuring the large quantities of methane released by rivers and streams shows that emissions depend on their connections to the surrounding landscape.
item.dc:title: A global picture of methane emissions from rivers and streams

item.title: LK-99 isn’t a superconductor — how science sleuths solved the mystery
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02585-7

Efforts to replicate the material have pieced together the puzzle of why it displayed superconducting-like behaviours.
item.dc:title: LK-99 isn’t a superconductor — how science sleuths solved the mystery
item.dc:creator: Dan Garisto

item.title: ‘Truly historic’: How science helped kids win a landmark climate trial
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02592-8

Lead attorney Julia Olson lays out what’s needed for future victories.
item.dc:title: ‘Truly historic’: How science helped kids win a landmark climate trial
item.dc:creator: Emma Marris

item.title: Immune treatment tackles chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02517-5

Smoking causes chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Some people with this disease have high levels of eosinophil cells, which is typical of the type 2 category of inflammation, and blocking such inflammation improves their lung health.
item.dc:title: Immune treatment tackles chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
item.dc:creator: John V. Fahy
Richard M. Locksley

item.title: Australia’s Antarctic budget cuts a ‘terrible blow for science’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02576-8

Scientists around the globe have expressed concern at reports that the Australian Antarctic Division will have its budget slashed by the government.
item.dc:title: Australia’s Antarctic budget cuts a ‘terrible blow for science’
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: A way to wipe a cell’s memory
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02381-3

Cells that have been artificially reprogrammed into states similar to embryonic stem cells — known as induced pluripotent stem cells — can bear a memory of their previous history. An innovative method that incorporates a step mimicking early development yields pluripotent cells that more closely resemble those in embryos, both on a molecular and functional level.
item.dc:title: A way to wipe a cell’s memory

item.title: Calligraphy tool offers clues to the origin of pancreatic cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02518-4

Understanding the processes that lead to tumour formation in the pancreas might help in efforts to develop therapies. A new bioinformatics tool called Calligraphy analyses cell–cell signalling to provide fresh insights into how tumours arise.
item.dc:title: Calligraphy tool offers clues to the origin of pancreatic cancer
item.dc:creator: Filip Bednar
Marina Pasca di Magliano

item.title: Mohammed Yahia (1982–2023)

Mohammed Yahia (1982–2023)
item.dc:title: Mohammed Yahia (1982–2023)

item.title: Drone missions uncover hidden features of the Battle of the Bulge
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02572-y

Laser-based system penetrates the deep forest covering the site of a key battle in the Second World War.
item.dc:title: Drone missions uncover hidden features of the Battle of the Bulge

item.title: Land sparing must protect common species too
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02568-8

Land sparing must protect common species too
item.dc:title: Land sparing must protect common species too
item.dc:creator: Magdalena Lenda
Piotr Skorka

item.content:encoded:

Heed a decade of calls for antibody validation
item.dc:title: Heed a decade of calls for antibody validation
item.dc:creator: Richard A. Kahn
Harvinder S. Virk
Peter S. McPherson

item.title: Physicists find a way to set a new marathon record
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02573-x

The right configuration of pacers could lead to the fastest marathon ever run.
item.dc:title: Physicists find a way to set a new marathon record

item.title: From the archive: a prize for the design of a helicopter, and a venomous caterpillar
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02354-6

Snippets from Nature’s past.

item.title: Abolish ageism in early-career research awards
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02567-9

Abolish ageism in early-career research awards
item.dc:title: Abolish ageism in early-career research awards
item.dc:creator: Fariba Karimi
Aaron Clauset

item.title: Can the world really stop wild polio by the end of 2023?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02577-7

Given that global efforts to eradicate the poliovirus were recently described as unsuccessful, how are Afghanistan and Pakistan now on the verge of eliminating it?
item.dc:title: Can the world really stop wild polio by the end of 2023?
item.dc:creator: Clare Watson

item.title: Daily briefing: Energy-sapping protein could be behind chronic fatigue
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02587-5

People with ME/CFS have high levels of a protein that disrupts cells’ energy production. Plus, why Hawaii’s wildfires are becoming more devastating and how to make the leap into industry after a PhD.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Energy-sapping protein could be behind chronic fatigue
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Beyond greenwashing: how to make business and finance genuinely sustainable
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02550-4

Researchers have a big role in unlocking funds for sustainability and ensuring that companies’ pledges are credible.
item.dc:title: Beyond greenwashing: how to make business and finance genuinely sustainable

item.title: Predatory journals entrap unsuspecting scientists. Here’s how universities can support researchers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02553-1

Training from institutions on publishing norms could help to thwart predatory publishers.
item.dc:title: Predatory journals entrap unsuspecting scientists. Here’s how universities can support researchers
item.dc:creator: Chérifa Boukacem-Zeghmouri

item.title: How to make the leap into industry after a PhD
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02558-w

Landing that first job in industry requires planning, homework and networking — and a bit of soul-searching.
item.dc:title: How to make the leap into industry after a PhD
item.dc:creator: Spoorthy Raman

item.title: Which birds are drab and which dazzle? Predators have a say
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02574-w

An analysis of almost 10,000 species identifies the life-history traits that explain why some birds flaunt a rainbow of ornamental colours.
item.dc:title: Which birds are drab and which dazzle? Predators have a say

item.title: Can oyster farming help save the planet?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02560-2

Ecologist Elena Tamburini hopes to show that shellfish farming efficiently absorbs carbon.
item.dc:title: Can oyster farming help save the planet?
item.dc:creator: Linda Nordling

item.title: How to reduce Africa’s undue exposure to climate risks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02557-x

Africa is disproportionately exposed to catastrophic climate, hydrological and meteorological risks. Well-funded weather monitoring, nowcasting and early-warning systems must become a priority.
item.dc:title: How to reduce Africa’s undue exposure to climate risks
